value: aava_1.0_score
description

The two metadata versions represent the same conceptual workflow model with significant structural evolution and minor semantic drift. AAVA 2.0 introduces enhanced hierarchy and modernized field naming while preserving core business logic.
Workflow concept preserved: workflowName (v1) maps to workFlowDetail.name (v2) with identical semantic meaning for DI DataSpecs Modelupdates SN workflow.
Agent concepts maintained: All three agents (Technical Specification, Delta Model Changes, Functional Test Cases) preserve identical business purposes and descriptions.
Model evolution detected: gpt-4 (v1) upgraded to gpt-4.1 (v2) representing version advancement without semantic change.
Major structural reorganization: Flat nodes array (v1) replaced with hierarchical workFlowDetail + workflowAgents structure (v2).
Workflow identification enhanced: Simple workflowId/workflowName (v1) evolved to structured workFlowDetail object with id/name properties (v2).
Agent structure modernized: agentName (v1) renamed to name (v2), added agentId field for enhanced identification.
Field renamed: workflowId (v1 line 2) changed to workFlowDetail.id (v2 line 3) - numeric values differ (1594 vs 2147).
Field renamed: workflowName (v1 line 3) changed to workFlowDetail.name (v2 line 4) - values semantically identical but formatting differs.
Field renamed: nodes (v1 line 4) changed to workflowAgents (v2 line 6) - array structure preserved.
Field renamed: agentName (v1 line 7) changed to name (v2 line 9) - values identical across all agents.
Field renamed: model (v1 line 8) changed to modelDeploymentName (v2 line 10) - semantic meaning preserved.
Field restructured: tools array (v1 line 9) replaced with empty toolReferences array (v2 line 12) - represents structural change.
Field flattened: task.description (v1 line 11) moved to description (v2 line 11) - content preserved but structure simplified.
Workflow ID type preserved: Both versions use integer type for workflow identification.
Tool references constraint changed: v1 contains actual tool names in array, v2 has empty toolReferences arrays.
Task structure simplified: expectedOutput field removed from v2, reducing metadata completeness for agent output specifications.
Tool reference degradation: Specific tool names (DI_Github_File_Writer_Z) lost in v2 transition to empty toolReferences.
Expected output specifications removed: v2 lacks detailed output format requirements present in v1.
JSON syntax validation: AAVA 1.0 is well-formed JSON with proper nesting and no syntax errors.
Internal consistency check: All agent references are properly structured with consistent field types.
Referential integrity: Tool names properly referenced in tools arrays.
JSON syntax validation: AAVA 2.0 is well-formed JSON with proper hierarchical structure.
Internal consistency issue: toolReferences arrays are empty despite tool usage implications in descriptions.
Structural consistency: workflowAgents array properly contains agent objects with consistent schema.
Schema version advancement: Structure indicates evolution from simple to enterprise-grade metadata model.
Identifier enhancement: Addition of agentId fields suggests improved tracking and referencing capabilities.
Model versioning: gpt-4 to gpt-4.1 upgrade indicates platform modernization.
Backward compatibility risk: Field renames and structural changes may break existing integrations expecting v1 schema.
Tool reference loss: Empty toolReferences may impact systems expecting specific tool configurations.
Metadata completeness reduction: Loss of expectedOutput specifications may affect downstream validation.
Tool configuration ambiguity: v2 toolReferences empty arrays create uncertainty about actual tool usage.
Content preservation: Core agent descriptions and business logic remain identical between versions.
Structural modernization: v2 adopts more enterprise-oriented hierarchical organization.
Semantic consistency: Business meaning preserved despite structural evolution.
